american.description: When you are starting on a project or a journey, it’s best to start with a good attitude and a lot of energy. First impressions (what people think about you when they meet you for the first time) can last for a long time. That’s why this proverb is also used when meeting new people or for job interviews. Having a positive attitude—your “best foot”—is the best way to make a good impression.

Boast not of tomorrow, for you know not what the day may bring forth.
Boldness does not always succeed.
Borrowed wives, like borrowed books, are seldom returned.
Bought friends are not friends indeed.
Boys seldom make passes at girls wearing glasses.
Boys will be boys.
Bragging saves advertising.
Brevity is the soul of wit.
Brooding may be very far from knowing.
Brothers are like hands and feet.
Bulls make money and bears make money, but hogs just get slaughtered.
Bury can’t and you’ll find will.
Bury your own dead.
Business goes where it is invited and stays where it is well treated.
Business is business, and love is love.
Business neglected is business lost.
Buy low, sell high.
Buy on the rumor; sell on the news.
Buying on credit is robbing next year’s crop.
By different methods different men excel.
By others’ faults wise men correct their own.
By the yard, life is hard. By the inch, it’s a cinch.
By their fruits you shall know them.
Call me anything but late for dinner.
Calm weather in June, sets the corn in tune.
Calmness is a great advantage.
Candour once went further boldly and in smiles, but it crept home in tatters and tears.
Candour will lose you some friends, but not as many as deceit.
Can’t have a family fuss without the whole town knowing about it.
Careless hurry may cause endless regret.
Cast the beam out of your own eye before you try to cast the mote from the eyes of your neighbour.
Catch before hanging.
Cats that wear gloves catch no mice.
Caution is a parent of safety.
Caution is the downfall to ambition.
Cease to do evil, learn to do well.
Certainty is better than hope.
Change of fortune hurts a wise man no more that a change of the moon.
Character is what we are; reputation is what others think we are.
Character is what you are in the dark when no one else is around.
Character is what you are in the dark.
Charity begins at home but should not end there.
Charity is a virtue of the heart and not of the hand.
Charity is not a bone you throw to your dog but a bone you share with your dog.
Chaste is she whom no one has asked.
Cheerful company shortens the miles.
Cheerfulness, helpfulness and honesty are fine, good companions to take with you through life.
Childhood should be happy and carefree.
Childhood shows the man as morning shows the day.
Choose you friends like your books: few but choice.
Choose your love, then love your choice.
Christmas comes, but once a year is enough.
Clean around your own back door before you clean around someone else’s.
Clean your own doorstep before you clean someone else’s.
Cleverness is serviceable for everything, sufficient for nothing.
Close enough for horseshoes and hand grenades.
Close, but no cigar.
Colleges hate geniuses, just as convents hate saints.
Coming events cast their shadows before.
Commerce flourishes by circumstances precarious.
Common sense is genius dressed in its working clothes.
Common sense is very uncommon with a lot of people.
Company in distress makes trouble less.
Comparisons make enemies of our friends.
Compromise makes a good umbrella but a poor roof.
Conceit is the self satisfaction of a jackass.
Condition is 90 percent of the game.
Confide not in him who has deceived you.
Confidence is a plant of slow growth.
Confidence of success is almost success.
Conscience is only another name for truth.
Consent to common custom, but not to common folly.
Consider whether your fun will cause another’s unhappiness.
Constant dripping wears away stone.
Constant occupation prevents temptation.
Contempt is the best return for scurrility.
Corn makes more at the mill than it does in the crib.
Count no man successful until he is dead.
Courage is fear that has said its prayers.
Courage without conduct is like a ship without ballast.
Courtesy is appropriate for gentlemen and necessary for thieves.
Courtesy is the password to safety.
Courtesy on one side only never lasts for long.
Cows can catch no rabbits.
Crap or get off the pot.
Credit is suspicion asleep.
Criticism is something you can avoid by saying nothing, doing nothing, and being nothing.
Crosses are the ladders to heaven.
Crotch seam rivet in original Levi’s dropped due to pain from standing near fires.
Crowning a clown won’t make him a king.
Cultivate friends who pray for you, not prey upon you.
Culture is one thing, and varnish is another.
Cunning is the ape of wisdom.
Cunning men deal in generalizations.
Curses, like chickens, come home to roost.
Custom is the great guide.
Custom surpasses nature.
Cut your losses and let your profits run.
Danger begets caution.
Danger is next neighbour to security.
Dare to be true; nothing can need a lie.
Dark days and storms heighten the appreciation of sunshine.
Darkness is the owl’s desire.
Death and taxes may be hard to beat.
Death devours lambs as well as sheep.
Death fiddles and we dance.
Death keeps no calendar.
Death rides with the drinking driver.
Death to the wolf is life to the lamb.
Debt is the worst kind of poverty.
Deceit is a lie which wears a smile.
Deceive not yourselves.
Deed done is well begun.
Deeds speak louder than words.
Deep calls unto deep.
Defeat isn’t bitter if you don’t swallow it.
Delays can be dangerous.
Delays increase desires and sometimes extinguish them.
Democracy is better than tyranny.
Demonstration is the best mode of instruction.
Despair is the conclusion of fools.
Desperate evils require desperate remedies.
Destiny leads the willing but drags the unwilling.
Diamonds come in small packages.
Different strokes for different folks.
Difficulties relate only to necessity.
Dig the well before you are thirsty.
Dignity does not consist in a silk dress.
Dignity is one thing that can’t be preserved in alcohol.
Diligence brings delight.
Diligence is the mistress of success.
Diligence is the mother of good luck.
Dime is money, as the Dutchman says.
Diplomacy is the art of letting someone else have your way.
Diplomacy is to do and say the nastiest thing in the nicest way.
Dirt is dirtiest upon clean white linen.
Dirt is dirtiest upon the fairest spot.
Dirty hands make clean money.
Disappointment hurts more than pain.
Discouragement is the devil’s most valuable tool.
Diseases are the tax on pleasures.
Disputing and borrowing cause grief and sorrowing.
Distance is the best remedy against an evil-disposed man.
Distance plants enchantment.
Distrust a prairie-dog and fix it.
Distrust and caution are the parents of security.
Do a good deed every day.
Do as well as you look.
Do it or dye!
Do not boast of a thing until it is done.
Do not disturb the water that is tranquil.
Do not look for wrong and evil.
Do not put your foot further than you can draw it back again.
Do not trust flatterers.
Do unto others as others do unto you.
Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. Do as you would be done by.
Do what you do carefully.
Do what you ought, come what may.
Doctor’s faults are covered with earth, and rich men’s with money.
Dogs delight to bark and bite for God has made them so.
Don’t bite off more than you can chew.
american.description: If you take a bite of food that’s too big, you won’t be able to chew! Plus you could choke on all of that extra food. It’s the same if you take on more work or responsibility than you can handle—you will have a difficult time. So it’s best not to get involved in too many projects, because you won’t be able to focus and get them all done well.

american.text: Don’t bite the hand that feeds you.
american.description: This proverb warns against acting mean to those who provide for you or who do nice things for you. If you were to bite the hand that gave you food, that hand probably won’t come back to feed you again. Then what would you eat? So you should be kind and thankful to those who care for you.

american.text: Walk lightly in the spring; Mother Earth is pregnant.
Of your unspoken words, you are the master; of your spoken words, the servant; of your written words, the slave
Silence is the cornerstone of character
Don’t count your chickens before they’ve hatched.
american.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.

american.text: Don’t cry over spilt milk.
Don’t make a mountain out of a molehill.
Don’t mistake chicken dung for an egg.
Don’t put robbers to work in a bank.
Don’t swap horses in midstream.
Don’t allow the grass to grow on the path of friendship.
Don’t ask a man for a favour before he has had his lunch.
Don’t believe your enemy even when he’s telling the truth.
Don’t bite the hand that feeds you.
american.description: This proverb warns against acting mean to those who provide for you or who do nice things for you. If you were to bite the hand that gave you food, that hand probably won’t come back to feed you again. Then what would you eat? So you should be kind and thankful to those who care for you.

american.text: Don’t burn the candle at both ends.
Don’t buy a cow to get a glass of milk.
Don’t care lost his corn patch.
Don’t cast your pearls before swine.
Don’t change horses while crossing a stream.
Don’t clean your fish before you catch it.
Don’t close the barn door after the horse runs away.
Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched.
american.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.

american.text: Don’t cry over spilled milk.
Don’t cry over spilt milk.
Don’t cry till you are out of the wood.
Don’t cut off your nose to spite your face.
Don’t do to others what you would not have done to you.
Don’t drown yourself to save a drowning man.
Don’t expect. Inspect.
Don’t fan the flame that supports the fire.
Don’t fire until you see the white of his eye.
Don’t hide your light under a bushel.
Don’t ignore the small things — the kite flies because of its tail.
Don’t judge a book by its cover.
american.description: Things are not always what they seem. This proverb teaches you not to make judgments about other people because of how they look or dress. A book with a boring or plain cover could be amazing. The same is true with people. A person might look like an athlete or fool, but there is probably a lot more to them than clothes suggest.

american.text: Don’t judge a man until you have walked two moons in his moccasins.
Don’t judge any man until you have walked two moons in his moccasins.
Don’t jump from the frying pan into the fire.
Don’t kick a dog when he is down.
Don’t kill the goose that lays the golden egg.
Don’t knock at a dead man’s door and expect an answer.
Don’t make a mountain out of a molehill.
Don’t make excuses, make good.
Don’t marry a girl who wants strawberries in January.
Don’t marry without love, but don’t love without reason.
Don’t measure your neighbor’s honesty by your own.
Don’t meddle in others’ affairs unless you want your own nose scraped a little.
Don’t mistake chicken dung for an egg.
Don’t mortgage the future for the present.
Don’t put all your eggs in one basket.
american.description: Be careful! If you put all your goods in one bag or all your money in one stock, you are taking a big risk. It is smarter to spread your wealth around. That way if one basket should break, you’re not left with nothing.

american.text: Don’t put the fox to guard the henhouse.
Don’t start economizing when you are down to your last dollar.
Don’t swing on my gate if you don’t like it.
Don’t take any wooden nickels.
Don’t talk unless you can improve the silence.
Don’t throw away your dirty water until you get clean.
Don’t throw dirt into the well that gives you water.
Don’t throw out the baby with the bath water.
Don’t throw out your dirty water until you get in fresh.
Don’t upset the apple cart.
Don’t use a lot where a little will do.
Don’t value a gem by what it is set in.
Doubt whom you will, but never doubt yourself.
Doubts — helped a man to live, to grow, or to build.
Dreams are what you hope for; reality is what you plan for.
Dreams are wishes your heart makes.
Dreams give wings to fools.
Drink and frankfurters for a dime; kill a man before his time.
Drink like hell and be happy.
Drive your business or it will drive you.
Drunken days have their tomorrow.
Durability is better than show.
Dying is as natural as living soundly.
Dying men speak true.
Dynamite comes in small packages.
Each day provides its own gifts.
Each husband gets the infidelity he deserves.
Eagles don’t catch flies.
Early childhood should be as happy and carefree as you can make it.
Earnest effort leads some to success.
Earth has no sorrow that heaven cannot heal.
East or west, home is best.
Easy come, easy go.
american.description: Money, fame, love or anything that happens easily can be lost just as quickly. If you get a lot of money or suddenly become famous, you could lose that money or fame very quickly—since you didn’t work hard to earn it.

american.text: Easy does it.
american.description: Be careful, don't go too fast.

american.text: Eat at pleasure; drink by measure.
Eat when you are hungry; drink when you are dry.
Eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow we shall die.
Eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow your wife may come home.
Eavesdroppers never hear any good of themselves.
Education doesn’t come by bumping your head against the school house.
Education is a gift that none can take away.
Education is the best provision for old age.
Eggs cannot be unscrambled.
Eggs can’t teach the hen.
Eleven don’t make a dozen.
Empty dishes rattle loudly.
Enough is enough and sometimes plenty.
Envy doesn’t enter an empty house.
Envy is a kind of praise.
Envy is blind.
Envy is destroyed by true friendship.
Envy is left-handed praise.
Equality begins in the grave.
Equals make the best friends.
Error can’t be defended by error.
Even a child makes himself known by his doings.
Even a dog knows the difference between being stumbled over and being kicked.
Even an ass loves to hear himself bray.
Even an ass will not fall twice in the same quick sand.
Every age wants its playthings.
Every animal knows more than you do.
Every doctor thinks his pills the best.
Every dog thinks her puppies are the cutest.
Every door may be shut but death’s door.
Every failure teaches a man something, if he will learn.
Every family has a goodness of mercy.
Every family has at least one black sheep.
Every man has a fool up his sleeve.
Every man has one black patch, and some have two.
Every man hath a fool in his sleeve.
Every man hath his hobby-horse.
Every man is a volume if you know how to read him.
Every man is occasionally what he ought to be perpetually
Every man’s your enemy till he proves your friend.
Every time you forgive a man you weaken him and strengthen yourself.
Every why has a wherefore.
Everyone for himself.
Everyone has his master.
Everyone knows where his shoe pinches.
Everyone lives downstream from someone else.
Everyone prefers his own.
Everything does not fall that totters.
Everything happens for a reason.
Everything is not all peaches and cream.
Everything worthwhile has a fence around it, but there is always a gate and a key.
Evil to him who evil does.
Example can be better than precept.
Experience is a comb which fate gives to a man when his hair is all gone.
Experience is a dear school, but fools learn in no other.
Experience is the father of wisdom and memory the mother.
Experience without learning is better than learning without experience.
Fact can be stranger than fiction.
Facts are better than theories.
Fair and softly goes far in a day.
Fair words butter no cabbage.
Fairest gems lie deepest.
Faith begins where reason stops.
Faith is that quality which enables us to believe what we know to be at least far out.
Faith is the vision of the heart.
Fall not out with a friend for a trifle.
False friends are worse than open enemies.
Falsehood is a nettle that stings those who meddle with it.
Falsehood is the darkness of faith.
Fame is longer than life.
Fate can be taken by the horns, like a goat, and pushed in the right direction.
Fear is a fine spur; so is rage.
Fear no man, and do justice to all men.
Feather by feather a goose is plucked.
Feed a cold, starve a fever.
Feed sparingly and defy the physician.
Fences mean nothing to those who can fly.
Few believe to err is human and to smack, divine.
Few things are easy to the unwilling.
Fidelity is a noble virtue, yet justice is nobler still.
Figures don’t lie, but sometimes liars figure.
Fire and flax agree not.
Fire is a good servant but a bad master.
Fireflies shine only when in motion.
First a daughter, then a son, and the family’s well begun.
First build your house and then accommodate the furniture.
First clean out your own backyard.
First deserve and then desire.
First endure, then pity, then embrace.
First there, first served.
Fish and visitors smell after three days.
Fish or cut bait.
Flattery butters no parsnips.
Flattery, like perfume, should be smelled, not swallowed.
Folks like the truth that hits their neighbor.
Folks spend their health to acquire wealth and later spend their wealth in an effort to regain their health.
Follow not truth too near the heels lest it dash out your teeth.
Follow the wise few rather than the vulgar many.
Fooled once shame on you, fooled twice shame on me.
Fools and children should never look at unfinished work.
Fools are never uneasy.
Fools die young and look sickly.
Fools enter where brave men fear to tread.
Fools fall the hardest.
Fools make feasts and wise men eat them.
Fools need advice most, but wise men only are the better for it.
Fools never prosper.
Fools were made to multiply.
For age and want save while you may, no morning sun lasts a whole day.
For every evil under the sun there is a remedy or there is none.
For every goose there is a gander.
Force is no argument.
Foresight is better than a night of terror.
Forgive and regret much later.
Fortune can take away riches but not courage.
Fortune favours fools.
Fortune is like price: if you can wait long enough, the price will fall.
Fortune makes friends; misfortune tries them.
Fortune never comes with both hands full.
Fraud and cunning are the weapons of the weak.
Free ships, free goods.
Fret not for yourself because of evildoers.
Fret today, regret tomorrow.
Friendly is as friendly does.
Friends and mules fail us in hard places.
Friendship is an empty word if it only works one way.
From beavers, bees should learn to mend their ways. A bee works; a beaver works and plays.
From errors of others a wise man corrects his own.
From little acorns mighty oaks do grow.
From middle age on, everything of interest is either illegal, immoral or fattening.
From small beginnings come great things.
From the cemetery no one is brought back.
Gambling is the son of avarice and the father of despair.
Garbage in, garbage out.
Gather rosebuds while you may.
Genius is one part inspiration and three parts perspiration.
Gentlemen prefer blonds — but marry brunettes.
Get what you can, and what you get, hold; it’s the stone that will turn all your lead into gold.
Getting things done is largely a matter of getting things started.
Getting what you go after is called success, but liking it while you are getting it is called happiness.
Give every man your ear but few your voice.
Give me flowers while I live.
Give some people everything you have and they still want the moon.
Give the devil his due.
God helps those who help themselves.
God promises a safe landing, but not a calm passage.
Gold is the devil’s fishhook.
Gold is where you find it.
Good Americans, when they die, go to Paris.
Good care prevents accidents.
Good enough for Government work.
Good fathers make good sons.
Good fences make good neighbors.
Good folks are scarce.
Good judgment comes from experience, and a lotta uh that comes from bad judgment.
Good listening does not mean sitting dumb.
Good luck beats early rising.
Good weight and measure, are heaven’s treasure.
Great deeds are reserved for great souls.
Great estates may venture more; little boats must keep near shore.
Great events give scope for great virtues.
Great trees keep little ones down.
Growing old is mandatory; growing up is optional.
Guard lest the eyes be bigger than the stomach.
Half an orange tastes as sweet as a whole one.
Handsome poverty is no disgrace.
Happiness is a form of courage.
Happiness multiplies as we divide it with others.
Haste is the mother of inaccuracy
Haste makes waste.
Have fun while you live, because you are going to be dead a long time.
Have the courage not to adopt another’s courage.
Having finished the meal, the company leaves.
He burned his own blister; now let him sit on it.
He is a fool that makes his doctor his heir.
He is a fool who cannot be angry but a wise man who will not.
He is dead that is faultless.
He is my friend that helps me, and not he that pities me.
He knows not the law who knows not the reason thereof.
He labours in vain who tries to please everybody.
He must have a long spoon who sups with the devil.
He that accuses all convicts only one.
He that can have patience can have what he will.
He that falls in love with himself will have no rivals.
He that fears leaves must not come into a wood.
He that fights and runs away may live to fight another day.
He that is angry is seldom at ease.
He that lives carnally won’t live eternally.
He that lives on hope has a slender diet.
He that lives on hope will die fasting.
He that makes a fire of straw has much smoke but little warmth.
He that marries for money will earn it.
He that pries into the clouds may be struck with a thunderbolt.
He that shows a passion tells his enemy where he may hit him.
He that swims in sin will sink in sorrow.
He that takes the devil into his boat must carry him over the sound.
He that will eat the kernel must crack the nut.
He that would make a fool of himself will find many to help him.
He travels fastest who travels alone.
He who asks more of a friend than he can bestow deserves to be refused.
He who associates with dogs learns to pant.
He who boasts of his descent is like a potato: the best part is underground.
He who can take advice is sometimes superior to those who give it.
He who drinks and walks away lives to drink another day.
He who has crossed the flood knows how deep it is.
He who has no future loses his grip on the present.
He who is born a fool is never cured.
He who is no friend to the good cause is no friend of mine.
He who is to break his neck finds the stairs in the dark.
He who judges others condemns himself.
He who laughs at others’ woes finds few friends and many foes.
He who laughs last laughs best.
He who lies down with dogs will rise with fleas.
He who never learns anything never forgets anything.
He who seeks equality should go to the cemetery.
Hear the evidence before you pass sentence.
Hell and the courtroom are always open.
Hell is full of good meanings, but heaven is full of good works.
Hell is populated with the victims of harmless amusements.
Here today, gone tomorrow.
He’s no fool who parts with what he can’t keep to get what he shall not lose.
Higher duties mean greater responsibilities.
Home is not a structure, but something in your heart.
Home is the father’s kingdom, the children’s paradise, the mother’s world.
Homely in the cradle, pretty at the table.
Honesty is like an icicle; if once it melts that is the end of it.
Honesty is praised and left to starve.
Honour to whom honour is due.
Honour your father and your mother.
Hope for the best, but prepare for the worst.
Hope is a good breakfast, but a poor supper.
Hope is the nurse of misery.
Hope of gain lessens pain.
Human nature is the same all the world over.
Hunger fetches the wolf out of the woods.
Hunger finds no fault with moldy corn.
I’d rather be red than dead.
I’d rather have them say "There he goes" than "Here he lies.".
If a man is right, he cannot be too radical; if wrong, he cannot be too conservative.
If a person’s foresight were as good as their hindsight, we would all get somewhere.
If fools went not to market bad wares would not be sold.
If he’s your flatterer, he can’t be your friend.
If it don’t seem like it’s worth the effort, it probably ain’t.
If it looks like a duck, walks like a duck, and quacks like a duck, it’s probably a duck.
If it were not for eating, the back might wear gold.
If it’s wrong to eat the devil, it’s wrong to drink his broth.
If luck is with you, even your ox will give birth to a calf.
If men could see the epitaphs their friends write they would believe they had gotten into the wrong grave.
If passion drives, let reason hold the reins.
If slavery isn’t wrong, nothing’s wrong.
If someone betrays you once, it is his fault. If he betrays you twice, it is your fault.
If the cap fits, wear it.
If the coat fits, put it on.
If the defendant is silent the jury will think him guilty.
If the dog hadn’t stopped to rest, he’d have caught the rabbit.
If the goat would not jump around, she wouldn’t break her leg.
If the heart is right, the head cannot be very far wrong.
If the shoe fits, put it on.
If the shoe fits, wear it.
If three people tell you that you are drunk, you better lie down.
If we blame others for our failures, then we should also give others credit for our successes.
If you act as good as you look, you’ll never shame your family.
If you are a cock, crow; if a hen, lay eggs.
If you are always dwelling in trouble, change your address.
If you ask a Negro where he’s been, he’ll tell you where he’s going.
If you can’t stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.
If you can’t help, don’t hinder.
If you can’t lick ’em, join `em.
If you can’t ride two horses at once, you shouldn’t be in the circus.
If you can’t say something good about someone, come sit right here by me.
If you can’t stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.
If you catch fish, you’re a fisherman.
If you cut down the trees you will find the wolf.
If you dance, you must pay the piper.
If you desire many things, many things will be seem but a few.
If you don’t believe in cooperation, watch what happens to a wagon when one wheel comes off.
If you don’t have a plan for yourself, you’ll be a part of someone else’s.
If you don’t know what to do, don’t do anything.
If you drive, don’t drink; if you drink, don’t drive.
If you eat a live toad first thing in the morning, nothing worse will happen all day long.
If you have no hand you can’t make a fist.
If you have wit and learning, add to it wisdom and modesty.
If you help the evil, you hurt the good.
If you look back, you’ll soon be going that way.
If you make yourself a doormat, you will be stepped on.
If you make yourself into a doormat, people will wipe their feet on you.
If you sing before breakfast, you’ll cry before night.
If you take care of your character, your reputation will take care of itself.
If you want anything well done, do it yourself.
If you want something done and done well, do it yourself.
If you want to keep friends don’t loan them any money.
If you want to keep something secret from black folks, put it between the covers of a book.
If you want to know the value of money, try borrowing some.
If you want to know what God thinks of money, look at the people he gives it to.
If you would enjoy its fruit, pluck not the blossom.
If you would enjoy the fruit, pluck not the flower.
If you’d be beloved, make yourself amiable.
If your time ain’t come not even a doctor can kill you.
If yuh ever find yurself in a hole, the first thin’ to do is stop diggin’.
If yur ridin’ ahead of the herd, take a look back every now and then to make sure it’s still there.
Ignorance is a form of environmental pollution.
Ignorance is bliss.
american.description: “Ignorance” is when you don’t know or are unaware of something. “Bliss” is pure joy and happiness. So sometimes it feels better and you’re more comfortable when you don’t know about certain things.

american.text: Imitation is the highest form of flattery.
In a united family, happiness springs up of itself.
In business partnerships and marriage partnerships, oh, the cheating that goes on.
In fair weather prepare for foul.
In God we trust; all others pay cash.
In great action, men show themselves as they ought to be, in small action as they are.
In order to judge another’s feelings, remember your own.
In politics, a man must learn to rise above principle.
In spring a young man’s fancy lightly turns to what the woman has been thinking all winter.
In the boy see the man.
In the South they don’t care how close you get, as long as you don’t get too high. In the North, they don’t care how high you get, as long as you don’t get too close.
In this world, nothing is permanent except change.
Industry is fortune’s right hand and frugality her left.
Industry keeps the body healthy, . . . and the purse full.
Industry need not wish.
Involve me, and I’ll understand.
It all depends on whose ox is gored.
It costs something to be a Christian, but it costs more to be a sinner.
It does not always rain when a pig squeals.
It doesn’t work to leap a twenty-foot chasm in two ten-foot jumps.
It don’t take no genius to spot a goat in a flock of sheep.
It is a man’s challenge to go as far as he can on the right road.
It is all right to drink like a fish if you drink what a fish drinks.
It is an easy matter for a stingy man to get rich — but what’s the use?
It is an ill thing to be deceived, but worse to deceive.
It is bad luck to fall out of a thirteenth story window on Friday.
It is better to ask twice than to go wrong once.
It is better to be a live rabbit than a tiger.
It is better to be alone than in bad company.
It is better to be lied about than to lie.
It is better to be right than in the majority.
It is better to be safe than sorry.
american.description: Do everything possible to keep bad things from happening to you. It only takes a second to put on a seatbelt or to check that you locked the door. But if you’re not safe, the bad results can last a lifetime. So it’s best for you to be careful, otherwise you’ll be sorry.

american.text: It is better to die young at home than to die old in a hospital.
It is better to have less thunder in the mouth and more lightning in the hand.
It is better to keep a wolf out of the fold than to trust drawing his teeth and talons after he shall have entered.
It is better to keep peace than to make peace.
It is better to know nothing than to half-know many things.
It is better to pay and have a little left than to have much and be always in debt.
It is better to sit with a wise man in prison than with a fool in paradise.
It is better to tell your money where to go than to ask where it went.
It is easy for a man in health to preach patience to the sick.
It is easy to be brave from a safe distance.
It is easy to despise what you can’t get.
It is easy to fool the young wolf.
It is good to have some friends both in heaven and in hell.
It is not as bad to believe a lie as to tell one.
It is not easy to straighten in the oak the crook that grew in the sapling.
It is not often that a man’s reputation outlasts his money.
It is not the clothes that count, but the things the clothes cover.
It is not well for a man to pray cream and live skim milk.
It is one thing to get educated and another thing to keep educated.
It is sometimes best to burn your bridges behind you.
It is the beautiful bird which gets caged.
It is the trapped animal that makes the most noise.
It is well that our faults are not written on our faces.
It isn’t the whistle that pulls the train.
It makes a difference if the pope is on your side.
It only looks that way.
It requires more courage not to fight than to fight.
It takes a heap of licks to strike a nail in the dark.
It takes a smart woman to be a fool.
It takes a thief to catch a thief.
It takes dough to have crust.
It takes half your life to learn who your friends are and the other half to keep them.
It takes nine months to have a baby, no matter how many people you put on the job.
It takes one to know one.
It takes three generation to make a gentleman.
It takes two to make a bargain.
It’s best to keep yer troubles pretty much to yerself, ‘cause half the people yu’d tell ‘em to won’t give a dang, and the other half will be glad to hear yu’ve got ‘em.
It’s a poor frog who doesn’t play with his own pond.
It’s all right to drink like a fish if you drink what a fish drinks.
It’s an ill army when the devil carries the colours.
It’s as difficult to win love as to wrap salt in pine needles.
It’s better to be a big frog in a little pond than a little frog in a big pond.
It’s better to tell your money where to go than to ask where it went.
It’s dog’s delight to bark and bite, but little children never.
It’s easier to go down than up.
It’s easier to lose faith than to find it again.
It’s more brave to live than to die.
It’s not every question that deserves an answer.
It’s not the gale but the set of the sail that determines the way you go.
It’s safer to commend the dead than the living.
Judge a Dutchman by what he means, not by what he says.
Judge men by their deeds, not be their creeds.
Justice delayed is justice denied.
Keep not ill company lest you increase the number.
Keep the weekdays honest and it will be easy to keep the Sabbath holy.
Keep your chickens in your own backyard.
Keep your eyes wide open before marriage, half shut afterwards.
Keep your foot on the mark.
Keep your friendship in repair.
Keep yourself from the opportunity and god will keep you from the sin.
Keeping from falling is better than helping up.
Kindle not a fire that you can’t extinguish.
Kindness is more binding than a loan.
Kissing a girl for the first time is like getting the first olive from a jar: after the first one, they come rolling out.
Knowledge conquered by labour becomes a possession.
Knowledge is proud that he knows so much; wisdom is humble that he knows no more.
Knowledge is the sister of folly.
Ladies in slacks should not turn their backs.
Laugh and grow fat.
Laugh and show your ignorance.
Laws too gentle are seldom obeyed; too severe, seldom executed.
Learn as you’d live forever; live as you’d die tomorrow.
Leave well enough alone.
Leaves enough, but few grapes.
Less advice and more hands.
Less said, more done.
Let every day provide for itself and God send Sunday.
Let every tub stand on its own bottom.
Let him who gives nothing be silent, and him who receives speak.
Let justice be done though the heavens fall.
Let the big dog eat.
Let the sleeping dog lie.
Let them laugh that win.
Let your actions be equal to your promises.
Let’s face the facts and get at the root of trouble.
Lettin the cat outta the bag is a whole lot easier’n puttin’ it back.
Liars begin by imposing on others, but end by deceiving themselves.
Life is a comedy to those who think, a tragedy to those who feel.
Life is a matter of dog eat dog.
Life is not a cup to be drained, but a measure to be filled.
Like a fence, character cannot be strengthened by whitewash.
Lime and lime without manure makes the farmer rich and the son poor.
Liquor never hurt a cheap man.
Listen or your tongue will keep you deaf.
Little brooks make great rivers.
Little folks are fond of talking about what great folks do.
Little pitchers have big ears.
Little said is soonest mended.
Little strokes fell great oaks.
Live and learn, die and forget it all.
Live your own life, for you die your own death.
Living in worry invites death in a hurry.
Lock the stable door before the steed is stolen.
Lock your door and keep your neighbours honest.
Long runs the fox, but at last is caught.
Look out for others and god will look out for you.
Looks often deceive.
Loose lips sink ships.
Love enters man through his eyes, woman through her ears.
Love many, trust few and always paddle your own canoe.
Love of dress is sure the very curse.
Love your neighbour, but do not pull down the fence.
Lovely women, lovely quarrels.
Lucky men need no counsel.
Lust never sleeps.
Lying rides upon debt’s back.
Make a garden or plant, and a man is happy for life.
Make a loan and lose a friend.
Make love, not war.
Make new friends but keep the old.
Make your brain save your heels.
Man cannot live by bread alone.
Man can’t live in this world alone.
Man changes often but improves seldom.
Man is greater than the tools he invents.
Man is like a banana: when he leaves the bunch, he gets skinned.
Man is the only animal who can be skinned twice.
Manhood is quite a struggle, old age a regret.
Mankind bestows more applause on her destroyer than on her benefactor.
Man’s only real possession is his character.
Many a flower is born to blush unseen.
Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage.
Many are called, but few are chosen.
Many drops of water make an ocean.
Many friends, few helpers.
Many have been ruined by buying good pennyworths.
Many speak much who cannot speak well.
Many words will not fill a bushel.
Marrying for love is risky, but god smiles on it.
Matches may be made in heaven, but they are sold down here.
Maternity is a matter of fact, paternity is a matter of opinion.
Measure twice before you cut once.
Men apt to promise are apt to forget.
Men are blind in their own cause.
Men are punished by their sins, not for them.
Men build houses; women build homes.
Men fear death as children do going in the dark.
Men seek less to be instructed than applauded.
Men shut their doors against the setting sun.
Men that have much business must have much pardon.
Money talks — everything else walks.
More corn grows in crooked rows.
More die of food than famine.
More flies are caught with honey than with molasses.
Most men get as good a wife as they deserve, and that isn’t much.
My son’s my son till he gets him a wife; my daughter’s my daughter all of her life.
Naught’s a naught and figger’s a figger – all for the white man and none for the nigger.
Necessity never made a good bargain.
Neither a borrower nor a lender be.
Never ask a barber if he thinks yuh need a haircut.
Never assent merely to please.
Never be content with your lot. Try for a lot more.
Never believe the impossible.
Never borrow, never lend if you wish to keep a friend.
Never complain. never explain.
Never criticize a man until you’ve walked a mile in his moccasins.
Never do evil hoping that good will come of it.
Never drop the friends you made on the way up. You may need them on the way down.
Never get in a battle of wits without ammunition.
Never judge by first impressions.
Never let the same dog bite you twice.
Never let your education interfere with your intelligence.
Never lie unless yuh have to, and if yuh don’t have a dang good lie, stick to the truth.
Never miss a good chance to shut up.
Never quarrel with one’s bread and butter.
Never say die.
Never stir the fire with a sword.
Never swap horses crossing a stream.
Never take to sawin’ on the branch that’s supportin’ you—unless you’re bein’ hung from it.
Never think of the future; it comes soon enough.
Never trouble trouble till trouble troubles you.
Never trouble trouble until trouble troubles you.
Never trust a man who doesn’t trust others.
Never try to prove what nobody doubts.
Never underestimate an enemy.
Never venture out of your depth till you can swim.
New churches and new bars are seldom empty.
Nice guys finish last.
Night brings the cows home.
Ninety per cent of inspiration is perspiration.
No ear is so deaf as one which wishes not to hear.
No friend is like an old friend.
No friendship can survive the gift of gold.
No garden without its weeds.
No matter how bad a child is, he is still good for a tax deduction.
No matter how you slice it, it’s still baloney.
No one can scatter his fire indefinitely.
No one else will do it for you.
No risk, no gain.
No river can return to its source, yet all rivers must have a beginning.
No rogue like the godly rogue.
Nobody gets out of the bed to sleep on the floor.
Nobody has ever bet enough on a winning horse.
None are deceived but they that confide.
None are so blind as those who refuse to see.
None but the wise man can employ leisure well.
Not everything forbidden is sweet.
Not he who has many ideas but he who has one conviction may become a great man.
Nothing is more durable than a hog’s snout.
Nothing ventured, nothing gained.
Observe with the eyes; listen with the ears; shut the mouth.
Of two evils, it is always best to vote for the less hypocritical.
Of your enemies say nothing.
Old age is ripeness.
Old brag is a good dog, but hold fast is better.
Old fishermen never die, they just smell that way.
Old foxes are not easily caught.
Old friends are the best, but new ones are the most fun.
Old shoes wear best.
On an unknown path every foot is slow.
Once bitten, twice shy.
Once out yonder tis only the rules that can save you—the rules of us pirates, that is.
One at a time is good fishing; two at a time is making a hog of yourself.
One clean sheet will not soil another.
One drink can lead to one’s downfall.
One evil breeds another.
One eyewitness could be better than ten hearsays.
One foot is better than two crutches.
One half the troubles in this world can be traced to saying ‘yes’ too quick or saying ‘no’ not soon enough.
One man with courage is a majority.
One man’s death is another man’s bread.
One man’s folly is another man’s fortune.
One may get up late if one has the name of getting up early.
One of the greatest labor-saving inventions of today is tomorrow.
One rotten apple can spoil a lot of good ones.
One seldom meets a lonely lie.
One should eat to live, not live to eat.
One tree can make a million matches, and one match can destroy a million trees.
One who cannot respect himself cannot respect another.
Only a fool argues with the cook.
Only fools and horses work.
Only live fish swim up stream.
Only those are fit to live who are not afraid to die.
Opportunities, like eggs, come one at a time.
Other people’s burdens killed the ass.
Our bread today is better than a hundred in the air.
Our crosses are hewn from different trees.
Our generosity should never exceed our abilities.
Our greatest deeds we do unknowingly.
Outward forms the inward man reveals.
Paddle together, bail, paddle; paddle, bail; paddle towards the land.
Pain is forgotten where gain comes.
Patience wears out stones.
Pay your debts or lose your friends.
Perhaps no one has a finer command of a language than he who keeps his mouth shut.
Perseverance is failing nineteen times and succeeding the twentieth.
Persistence will accomplish more than force.
Philosophy means being able to explain why you are happy when you are poor.
Plough your furrows deep while sluggards sleep, and you shall have corn to sell and to keep.
Poets are born, not made.
Politics makes strange bedfellows.
Possession is nine-tenths of the game.
Poverty with security is better than plenty in the midst of fear and uncertainty.
Practice what you preach.
american.description: If you say that everyone needs to arrive on time, make sure that you also arrive on time.

american.text: Praise makes a bad man worse.
Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition.
Prayer is a wish turned upward.
Prayer is food for the soul.
Pride is said to be the last vice the good man gets clear of.
Pride is the last vice a good man gets clear of.
Pride often apes humility.
Pride that dines on vanity sups on contempt.
Professionals built the ‘Titanic,’ amateurs built the ark.
Profit by the folly of others.
Promise little but do much.
Promise little but with respect.
Promises fill no sack.
Put cream and sugar on a fly and it tastes very much like a black raspberry.
Put first things first.
american.description: This proverb advises you to do things in the right order. Do not skip over the more difficult or less enjoyable tasks in order to get to the easier, more fun ones.

american.text: Put up or shut up.
Put your money where your mouth is.
Put your trust in God, and keep your powder dry.
Putting the cart before the horse.
Quarreling dogs come halting home.
Quiet people, whether wise or dull, get the benefit of the doubt.
Ragged colts make fine horses.
Rather than run into debt, wear your old coat.
Reading makes a full man, meditation a profound man, discourse a clear man.
Real friendship is a slow grower.
Real happiness is found not in doing the things you like to do, but in liking the things you have to do.
Reality never surpasses imagination.
Reason succeeds where force fails.
Religion is the best armor in the world, but the worst cloak.
Republicans will do anything for the poor except get off their backs.
Reputation is what you are in the light; character is what you are in the dark.
Rise early, live soberly, and apply yourself with industry.
Romance/ without finance/ don’t stand a chance.
Roots of evil bear bitter fruits.
Saying and doing are two different things.
Scandal will rub out like dirt when it is dry.
Scratch my back and I’ll scratch yours.
See the weakest fruit drops earliest to the ground.
Seek not to be consoled but to console.
Self-conceit may lead to self-destruction.
Self-help is the best help.
Send a fool to the market, and a fool he’ll return.
Set a frog on a golden stool, away it hops to reach the pool.
She who is a beauty is half married.
Sheep-killing dogs are vicious.
Show me, and I may not remember.
Silence is golden, speech is silver.
Silence is the best answer to the stupid.
Silks and satins, scarlet and velvet, put out the kitchen fire.
Sin concealed needs two forgivings.
Six feet of earth makes all men equal.
Slander not the dead.
Slow help is no help.
Small evils hatch quick.
Smith and Wesson or a Colt always beat four aces.
Solid learning makes a man fit company for himself.
Some are born to honor, and some have honor thrust upon them.
Some families are like potatoes — all that’s good of them is underground.
Some folks speak from experience; others, from experience, don’t speak.
Some will, some don’t, so what!
Some will, some don’t, so what.
Sometimes the remedy is worse than the disease.
Sooner or later perseverance achieves.
Spare at the brim, not at the bottom.
Speak fair, think what you will.
Speak kind words and you will hear kind answers.
Speak when you are spoken to.
Speed will get you nowhere if you are headed in the wrong direction.
Stand up, cent, let the dollar sit down.
Step on a crack break your mother’s back.
Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me.
Still achieving, still pursuing.
Stopping at third base adds no more to the score than striking out.
Strike while your employer has a big contract.
Strive for the summit.
Strive though you fail.
Study the past if you would divine the future.
Success has many fathers, but failure is an orphan.
Success is a ladder that cannot be climbed with your hands in your pockets.
Success never needs an excuse.
Success ruins a fool.
Suspicion may be no fault, but showing it may be a great one.
Sweep around your own doorstep first.
Sweep before your own door before you sweep before others.
Sweep the dirt from in front of your own door, and don’t worry about your neighbour’s.
Tact is the art of making a point without making an enemy.
Take a friend for what he does, a wife for what she has, and goods for what they are worth.
Take all you want, but eat all you take.
Take care of the dimes and the dollars will take care of themselves.
Take care of your pennies and your dollars will take care of your widow’s next husband.
Take each day as it comes.
Take opportunity by the forelock.
Take the bitter with the sweet.
Take two and hit to right.
Talk is cheap but it takes money to buy whiskey.
Temper your enthusiasm with judgement.
Thanks is poor pay on which to keep a family.
That which comes from the heart is always sincere.
The aim is useless without the way.
The anvil fears no blows.
The ardor of parental affection consumes the heart with its fire.
The artist never dies.
The ass knows in whose face he brays.
The baby who always gets carried will never learn to walk.
The bad gardener quarrels with his rake.
The bad workman blames his tools.
The best advice I know in life is don’t give too much.
The best chaperon a girl can have is to be in love with another fellow.
The best fishing is in the deepest waters.
The best laid plans of mice and men often go astray.
The best part of a book is not the thought it contains but the thought it suggests.
The best way to get someone to stop digging his heels in is to dig out the sand around him.
The best way to get something done is to do it yourself.
The best way to have a friend is to be a friend.
The best way to keep friends is not to give them away.
The best way to kill time is to work it to death.
The better the day, the better the deed.
The bigger the tree, the harder she falls.
The biggest rascal you’ll probably ever need to deal with watches you shavin’ his face in the mirror every mornin’.
The blacker the berry the sweeter the juice.
The busy man has few idle visitors: to the boiling pot the flies come not.
The cat may look at the queen.
The cemeteries are filled with people who thought the world couldn’t get along without them.
The chickens have come home to roost.
The child is the father of the man.
The church bell sometimes does better work than the sermon.
The cow has forgotten she was once a calf.
The cuckold is the last that knows of it.
The customer’s always right.
The daughter of a spry old woman makes a poor housekeeper.
The dead are soon forgotten.
The deities of one age are the bywords of the next.
The devil always tends to his own business.
The devil can quote Scripture to his own advantage.
The devil is always at the elbow of an idle man.
The devil never misses the bus.
The devil protects his own.
The devil takes care of his own.
The dictionary is the only place where success comes before work.
The difference between adults and children is that adults don’t ask questions.
The disgrace of the city is the fault of the citizens.
The distant fields look greener.
The dog doesn’t get bread every time he wags his tail.
The dog has returned to his vomit again, and the sow that was washed to her wallowing in the mire.
The dog that minds not your whistle is good for nothing.
The doghouse is no place to keep a sausage.
The downward road is easy.
The early bird catches the worm.
american.description: This proverb is a lot like the phrase “first come, first served.” It simply means that it’s usually best to be early. If you arrive earlier—whether it’s to a clothing store, restaurant, conference, etc.—you will have the best options to choose from. If you come later, though, the best clothes could have sold out, the restaurant could be full and have a long waiting time, etc.

american.text: The early bird gets the worm.
american.description: Start working early and you will be successful.

american.text: The early bird may catch the worm, but the second mouse gets the cheese.
The easiest way to get a divorce is to be married.
The end crowns all.
The end of the thief is the gallows.
The face is a mask; look behind it.
The face is the index of the mind, but appearances are deceitful.
The farmer feeds them all.
The fates lead the willing man; an unwilling man they drag.
The fire you kindle for your enemy often burns yourself more than him.
The first attempt is the most difficult.
The first hundred years are the hardest.
The fool wanders; the wise man travels.
The forest is the poor man’s overcoat.
The frog does not drink up the pond in which he lives.
The frost will bring the pig home.
The fruit doesn’t fall far from the tree.
The future belongs to those who prepare for it.
The garment of peace never fades.
The generous can forget that they have given, but the grateful can never forget that they have received.
The giver makes the gift precious.
The good lawyer knows the law, the clever one knows the judge.
The great man is he who does not lose his child’s heart.
The greatest art is the art of life.
The ground of liberty must be gained by inches.
The happiest place in the world to live is within one’s income.
The heart has arguments with which the understanding is unacquainted.
The heart has eyes that the brain knows nothing of.
The higher they fly, the harder they fall.
The higher you climb, the harder you may fall.
The intelligence of the average individual reaches its lowest ebb when he enters a railroad station.
The king’s cheese goes half away in parings.
The lazy ox drinks dirty water.
The length of a conversation don’t tell nothin’ ‘bout the size of the intellect.
The less we know, the more we suspect.
The longest day will come to an end.
The longest mile is the last mile home.
The loudest bell does not always have the sweetest tone.
The love of evil is the root of all money.
The man that blushes is not quite a brute.
The man who flatters you is a liar: the greater the flattery, the bigger the liar.
The man who loves to argue is left without friends.
The man who minds his own business generally has a good one.
The more acquaintances, the more danger.
The more arguments you win, the less friends you will have.
The more responsibilities a man assumes, the more likely he is to meet them.
The more sins you confess, the more books you will sell.
The more you eat, the more you want.
The more you stir dirt, the worse it stinks.
The most dangerous food is a wedding cake.
The most destructive criticism is indifference.
The mountains are never so far apart but the animals find one another.
The mouth of fools pours out foolishness.
The obvious choice is usually a quick regret.
The older the fool, the harder he falls.
The only difference between stumbling blocks and stepping stones is the way you use them.
The only sure thing about luck is that it’s sure to change.
The only thing a heated argument ever produced is coolness.
The only thing we learn from new elections is we learned nothing from the old.
The opera isn’t over till the fat lady sings.
The opportunity of a lifetime is seldom so labeled.
The outward forms the inward man reveal – we guess the pulp before we cut the peel.
The passions are like fire and water: good servants but bad masters.
The Pilgrim Fathers landed on the shores of America and fell on their knees; then they fell upon the aborigines.
The quickest way to double yur money is to fold it over and put back it in yur pocket.
The rain follows after the forest.
The real owners of the land are not yet born.
The reason some people are stingy is also the reason they are rich.
The receiver is as bad as the thief.
The rich get richer, and the poor get babies.
The river is my brother for it carries my canoe.
The road to ruin is kept in good repair, and the travellers pay the expense.
The road to the head lies through the heart.
The saddest dog sometimes wags its tail.
The secret of life is not to do what you like, but to like what you do.
The shortest distance between two points is a straight line.
The shortest follies are the best.
The show must go on.
The simplest things are the most startling.
The sleeping fox catches no chickens.
The small courtesies sweeten life; the greater, ennoble it.
The sound of a church bell at times has more effect than a sermon.
The tail can’t shake the dog.
The tiger crouches before he leaps upon his prey.
The tougher the fight, the sweeter the triumph.
The truth is better than a lie.
The truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.
The unknown is always great.
The very time I thought I was lost, my dungeon shook and my chains fell off.
The way to avoid great faults is to b aware of little ones.
The weaker the argument, the stronger the words.
The weed of arrogance grows on a dunghill.
The wicked work harder to preach hell than the righteous do to get to heaven.
The wise and the fool have their fellows.
The wise man keeps his own counsel.
The wish is the father of the deed.
The world is a ladder for some to go up and others down.
The worm turns.
The young may die; the old must die.
There ain’t no such thing as a free lunch.
There are always more fish in the pond.
There are many echoes in the world, but few voices.
There are many kinds of fruit that grow on the tree of life, but none so sweet as friendship.
There are many who prefer to despise and belittle that which is beyond their reach.
There are many witty men whose brains can’t fill their bellies.
There are more ways than one to kill a cat.
There are more ways to kill a dog than by choking him on peanut butter.
There are not so many who must feign madness to survive.
There are other fish in the sea.
There are three faithful friends: an old wife, an old dog, and ready money.
There are three kinds of people; those that make things happen, those that watch things happen and those who don’t know what’s happening.
There are three things that can destroy a preacher, the glory, the gold, and the girls.
There are two sides to every story—and then there’s the truth.
There be treasure in them thar hills.
There is a remedy for everything, could we but hit upon it.
There is a time to fish and a time to dry nets.
There is delight in danger and danger in delight.
There is many a slip ‘twixt cup and lip.
There is more to honesty than meets the eye.
There is no accounting about tastes.
There is no disgrace in honest labour.
There is no education like adversity.
There is no lie spun so fine, through which the truth won’t shine.
There is no little enemy.
There is nothing better than a good woman and nothing worse than a bad one.
There is only one blasphemy, and that is injustice.
There isn’t a aascAt or a thief that doesn’t have his devotion.
There must be a first time for everything.
There’s no use asking the cow to pour you a glass of milk.
There’s two theories to arguin’ with a woman—and neither one works.
There’s a fool born every minute.
There’s a pot gold at the end of the rainbow.
There’s always a bad egg in every crowd.
There’s more than one way to beat the devil around the bush.
There’s no advice like father’s — even if you don’t take it.
There’s no fun in physics, but a good deal of physics in fun.
There’s no place like home.
There’s no such thing as a horse that can’t be rode or a cowboy that can’t be throwed.
There’s no use asking the cow to pour you a glass of milk.
There’s no use in closing the barn door after the horse is stolen.
There’s no use to pray after the devil has you.
They die well that live well.
They who drink beer think beer.
They who play with edged tools must expect to be cut.
Thieves hunt in couples, but a liar has no accomplice.
Think twice before you speak to a friend in need.
Those above are going down, those below are going up.
Those that never had a cushion never need one.
Those who betray their friends must not expect others to keep faith with them.
Those who sleep with dogs gets up with fleas.
Those who take the profits should also bear the expense.
Those who think they can’t are generally right.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
Though the fox wear silk, he is still a fox.
Threatened folks may live the longest: they take numerous precautions.
Three — friends: an old wife, an old dog, and ready money.
Three faithful friends: an old wife, an old dog, and ready money.
Thrift is to a man what chastity is to a woman.
Through wisdom is a house built, and by understanding it is established.
Tigers and deer do not stroll together.
Time and tide wait for no man.
Time heals all wounds.
Time saved at the cost of an accident is no saving.
Timin’ has a lot to do with the outcome of a rain dance.
’tis the taste that tells the tale.
To be a public man is slavery.
To be proud of knowledge is to be blind with light.
To be successful in love, one must know how to begin and when to stop.
To be trusted is a greater compliment than to be loved.
To become a father is easy, but to be a father is difficult.
To carry care to bed is to sleep with a pack on your back.
To command one must learn to obey.
To do nothing is the way to be nothing.
To err is human; to dine, divine.
To err is human; to keep it up is folly.
To favor the ill is to injure the good.
To forget is impossible.
To forgive a duke his tyranny alters not the total situation.
To have a friend, close one eye; to keep him, close both.
To know all is to forgive all.
To laugh at a man with sense is the privilege of fools.
To one who understands, few words are needed.
To plough a straight furrow, never look back.
To see beauty you must have beauty in your soul.
To spoil a child is to maim it a bit.
Today is the first day of the rest of your life.
Tongue double brings trouble.
Too far east is west.
Too many cooks spoil the brew.
Too many fingers spoil the pie.
Too much attention to the pigskin doesn’t help the sheepskin.
Too much courtesy, too much craft.
Too much force breeds suspicion.
Too much prosperity makes most men fools.
True bravery is without witness.
True friends are like diamonds, precious and rare; false ones like autumn leaves, found everywhere.
True friends never polish each other.
True generosity is the ability to accept ingratitude.
True worth is in being, not seeming.
Trust in god but lock your car.
Truth may be blamed but never shamed.
Try the ice before you venture on it.
Try your friend before you trust him.
Turnabout is fair play.
Two’s company, three’s a crowd.
Use your wit as a shield, not as a dagger.
Variety is the spice of life.
american.description: Make sure to try all sorts of things in your life. Otherwise, you'll get bored.

american.text: Walk on your own feet.
Warm weather in June sets the corn in tune.
Watch out for wooden nickels.
We ain’t what we want to be; we ain’t what we gonna be; but thank God, we ain’t what we was.
We all fade as the leaf.
We all live downwind.
We always return to our first loves.
We are as big as the thing which bothers us.
We can be deceived by fair appearance.
We do not inherit the land from our ancestors; we borrow it from our children.
We easily disbelieve those things which we desire not.
We hate those who will not take our advice and despise those who do.
We judge others by their acts, but ourselves by our intentions.
We may give advice, but we cannot give conduct.
We must all eat a peck of dirt before we die.
We must take the bitter with the better.
We see least with borrowed eyes.
We seldom fear what we can laugh at.
We’ll cross that bridge when we get to it.
Weak men wait for opportunities, strong men make them.
Wealth consists not of having great possessions but of having few wants.
Welcome is the best dish on the table.
What a fool does in the end, the wise man does in the beginning.
What a man can be is born with him; what he becomes is a result of his environment.
What a story these old walls could tell.
What goes around comes around.
What is an expert? Someone who is twenty miles from home.
What isn’t your duty isn’t your business.
What one fool can do, another can.
What the eye can’t see, the heart won’t crave.
What the people believe is true.
Whatever nature does least, man does most.
What’s the good of a fair apple if it has a worm in its heart?
When a badman dies, he either goes to hell or to the Pecos.
When a dog bites a man, that is not news; but when a man bites a dog, that is news.
When a father praises his son, he flatters himself.
When a girl whistles, the angels cry.
When a man is down, everyone runs over him.
When a man say him do not mind, then him mind.
When death knocks at your door, you must answer.
When fools make mistakes, they lay the blame on providence.
When fortune knocks, open the door.
When in charge, ponder. When in trouble, delegate. When in doubt, mumble.
When in doubt, don’t.
When in doubt, find out.
When in doubt, win the trick.
When life hands you lemons, make lemonade.
When one door shuts, another opens.
When pleasure interferes with business, give up business.
When the ale is in, wit is out.
When the apple gets ripe, it’s likely to fall.
When the bait’s worth more than the fish, it’s time to stop fishing.
When the candles are all out, all women are fair.
When the dead man sings it may last a very long time.
When the eagle is dead, the crows pick out his eyes.
When the fox preaches, beware of your geese.
When the fruit fails, welcome haws.
When the glow worm lights her lamp, the air is always very damp.
When the law is against you, argue the facts. When the facts are against you, argue the law. When both are against you, change the subject.
When the water’s high, the boat’s high.
When the white man wins, it is a battle.
When you argue with a fool, make sure he is not doing the same.
When you buy friends with anything other than friendship, they do not stay bought long.
When you go to dance, take heed whom you take by the hand.
When you persuade, speak of interest, not of reason.
When you see gossamer flying, be sure the air is drying.
When you see the gossaner flying, be sure the air is drying.
When you throw dirt, you lose ground.
When you were born, you cried and the world rejoiced. Live you life in a manner so that when you die the world cries and you rejoice.
When you’re trying’ somethin’ new, the fewer people that know about it, the better.
When your neighbour’s house is on fire, beware of your own.
Where law ends, tyranny begins.
Where the carcass is, there the ravens will collect together.
Where the carrion is, there the eagles gather.
Where the woman wears the breeches, she has a good right to them.
Where there’s smoke, there’s fire.
Where there’s smoke, there’s toast.
Where’s the loot?
Who avoids temptation avoids sin.
Who busies himself where no profit is found remains a fool the whole year round.
Who has drunk will drink.
Who is great in faith won’t be small in failure.
Who never doubted never half believed.
Who pleasure gives shall joy receive.
Who rewards evil for good, evil shall not depart his house.
Whoever gossips to you will gossip of you.
Whom chance often passes by, it finds at last.
Why buy the cow when you can get the milk for free?
Wide experience makes for deep tolerance.
Wisdom doesn’t always speak in Greek and Latin.
Wise men learn from other men’s mistakes; fools insist on learning from their own.
Wishes won’t wash dishes.
With age comes wisdom.
With the old year leave your faults, however dear.
Without justice, courage is weak.
Women are like books: too much gilding makes men suspicious that the binding is the most important part.
Words and deeds are not weighed in the same balance.
Work well done makes pleasure more fun.
Worms don’t like the robin’s song.
Would you persuade, speak of interest, not of reason.
Wrinkled purses make wrinkled faces.
Years know more than books.
You are judged not by what you have but by what you do with what you have.
You are never too young to die.
You can always tell a drunkard by his actions.
You can bear with your own faults, and why not a fault in your wife?
You can build a house but you must make a home.
You can drive sixty miles a minute, but there is no future in it.
You can fool an old horse once but you can’t fool him twice.
You can get far with a lie, but not come back.
You can go home when you can go nowhere else.
You can hardly keep from getting soiled if you fight with a skunk.
You can lead a horse to water, but you can’t make it drink.
You can never tell what’s in a package by its cover.
You can run into debt, but you have to crawl out.
You can shear a sheep many times but you can skin him only once.
You can shut the door on a thief, but you can do nothing about a liar.
You cannot drive a windmill with a pair of bellows.
You cannot have all chiefs; you gotta have Indians too.
You cannot squeeze blood out of a stone.
You cannot unscramble eggs.
You can’t be a howling success by simply howling.
You can’t blame a dentist for looking down at the mouth.
You can’t catch fish on a dry line.
You can’t fit a round peg in a square hole.
You can’t fly with one wing.
You can’t get there from here.
You can’t hold another fellow down in the ditch unless you stay down there with him.
You can’t jest an enemy into a friend, but you can jest a friend into an enemy.
You can’t keep the birds from flying over your head, but you can keep them from building a nest in your hair.
You can’t kid your conscience.
You can’t lose what you haven’t got.
You can’t see the sun when you’re crying.
You can’t steal second base with your foot on first.
You can’t take a second drink unless you have taken a first.
You can’t tell a book by its cover.
You can’t tell the depth of the well by the length of the handle on the pump.
You can’t trust your best friend.
You can’t unscramble an egg.
You can’t unscramble eggs.
You can’t unscramble scrambled eggs.
You don’t get what you deserve, you get what you negotiate.
You don’t need decorated words to make yer meanin’ clear. Say it plain, and save some breath for breathin’.
You don’t put robbers to work in a bank.
You have to be smarter than the dog to teach him tricks.
You have to crawl before you can walk.
You have to kiss a lot of toads before you find a handsome prince.
You made your bed, now lie in it.
You make a mountain of a mole-hill.
You may choose your friends; your family is thrust upon you.
You might as well die with the chills as with the fever.
You must cut your coat according to your cloth.
You must not enthrone ignorance just because there is much of it.
You must pay the fiddler if you want to dance.
You need more than dancing shoes to be a dancer.
You need not grease a fat sow.
You will always be lucky if you know how to make friends with strange cats.
You will never find a cat on a cold hearth.
You’ll hear a lot of things before your ears drop off.
Young courage and old caution are a strong pair.
Your best friend is yourself.
Your failures could be stepping-stones to success.
Your first accident may be your last.
Your ignorance is your worst enemy.
Your own faults look as big to the other fellow as his do to you.
Your sins will find you out.
Your thoughts go no farther than your vocabulary.
Your whole destiny is involved in the attitude you take toward your sin.
A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
A bird is known by his note and a man by his talk.
A brother may not be a friend . . .
A carpenter is known by his chips.
A diamond on a dunghill is a precious diamond still.
A disease known is half cured.
A dog is a man’s best friend.
A drowning man grabs at a straw.
A flow will have an ebb.
A fool and his money are soon parted.
A fool talks with his ears stuffed up.
A friend in need is a friend indeed.
A friend who shares is a friend who cares.
A full ear of corn will bend its head; an empty ear will stand upright.
A gentle disposition is like an unruffled stream.
A good example is the best sermon.
A leopard cannot change its spots.
A light cinch is best.
A little bit of powder and a little bit of paint make a woman look like what she ain’t.
A little courtesy will go a long way.
A man can die just once.
A man is known by the company he keeps.
A man without a smiling face must not open a shop.
A miss is as good as a mile.
A neglected duty may return tomorrow with seven others on its back.*
A place for everything and everything in its place.
A sure sign of age is loneliness.
A vicious man cannot appreciate the graces of a virtuous wife.
A wise man learns by the experiences of others; an ordinary man learns by his own experience; a fool learns by nobody’s experiences.
A wise man’s day is worth a fool’s life.
Absence makes the heart grow fonder.
Abundance, like want, ruins many.
Action is the proper fruit of knowledge.
Actions speak louder than words.
american.description: The Greek philosopher Plato once said that action is character. People are not defined by what they say because a lot of talk does not mean anything. People are judged by the things they do. Your actions are more important than what you say.

american.text: Adversity will rid the spendthrift of her sycophants.
Advisers get away with it. They never have to pay the penalty *for their advice.
After the feast comes the reckoning.
All asses do not go on four feet.
All that glitters is not gold.
All that shines is not silver.
All the branches of a tree do not lean the same way.
Ambition is like hunting for whales – sometimes you lose them.*
An adult is only one who has ceased to grow vertically and started to grow horizontally.
An ant may work its heart out, but it can’t make money.
An apple a day keeps the doctor away.
american.description: An apple is full of Vitamin C, which keeps you healthy. However, the “apple” in this proverb means eating healthy in general. If you eat well and your diet includes a lot of fruits and vegetables, there will be no need to visit the doctor.

american.text: An eel held by the tail is not yet caught.
An empty sack won’t stand alone.
An open gate lets stock out.
An ounce of discretion is worth a pound of wit.
Art is the right hand of nature.
At the end of the work, you may judge the workman.
Bad news travels fast.
Barking dogs seldom bite.
Be certain and on the level.
Be gay today, for tomorrow you may die.
Be just before you are generous.
Be nice to people on your way up because you’ll med them on your way down.
Beautiful peaches are not always the best flavoured.
Beauty and folly are old companions.
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Beauty is no longer amiable than while virtue adorns it.
Before marriage open your eyes wide; afterwards close them tightly.
Beggars can’t be choosers.
american.description: If someone gives you free things or offers to help you do something, you can’t ask for a different color or choose the perfect time in your schedule. When you receive free help or goods, you should accept what you’re offered—you can’t be picky (a “chooser”) because you’re not paying!

american.text: Begin in time to finish without hurry.
Better a donkey that carries me than a horse that throws me.
Better a live coward than a dead hero
Better go around than fall into the ditch.
Better late than never.
american.description: While being the early bird is the best, even latecomers may get something for coming. It would be a lot worse if they never came at all. This proverb is said about ending fights with people. It’s better to apologize and make up years later, than to never resolve your fight at all.

american.text: Better safe than sorry.
Birds of a feather flock together.
Blood is thicker than water.
american.description: Remember he's your brother. That relationship will always remain.

american.text: Boldness does not always succeed.
Bought friends are not friends indeed.
Boys will be boys.
By their fruits you shall know them.
Certainty is better than hope.
Charity begins at home but should not end there.
Charity begins at home.
Chaste is she whom no one has asked.
Cheerful company shortens the miles.
Children are often coming without being called.
Christmas comes but once a year.
Clean around your own back door before you clean around someone else’s.
Clean your own doorstep before you clean someone else’s.
Clothes do not make the man.
Coming events cast their shadows before.
Common sense is genius dressed in its working clothes.
Crap or get off the pot.
Crowning a clown won’t make him a king.
Culture is one thing, and varnish is another.
Curiosity killed the cat.
american.description: This proverb is often used to stop someone from asking too many questions.

american.text: Darkness is the owl’s desire.
Death and taxes may be hard to beat.
Deep calls unto deep.
Delays can be dangerous.
Different strokes for different folks.
Dig the well before you are thirsty.
Dime is money, as the Dutchman says.
Distrust and caution are the parents of security.
Do as I say, not as I do.
Do not boast of a thing until it is done.
Do not trust flatterers.
Dogs delight to bark and bite for God has made them so.
Don’t ask a man for a favour before he has had his lunch.
Don’t bit the hand that feeds you.
Don’t bite off more than you can chew.
american.description: If you take a bite of food that’s too big, you won’t be able to chew! Plus you could choke on all of that extra food. It’s the same if you take on more work or responsibility than you can handle—you will have a difficult time. So it’s best not to get involved in too many projects, because you won’t be able to focus and get them all done well.

american.text: Don’t clean your fish before you catch it.
Don’t close the barn door after the horse runs away.
Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched.
american.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.

american.text: Don’t cry over spilt milk.
Don’t cut off your nose to spite your face.
Don’t do to others what you would not have done to you.
Don’t hide your light under a bushel.
Don’t judge a book by its cover.
american.description: Things are not always what they seem. This proverb teaches you not to make judgments about other people because of how they look or dress. A book with a boring or plain cover could be amazing. The same is true with people. A person might look like an athlete or fool, but there is probably a lot more to them than clothes suggest.

american.text: Don’t judge a man until you’ve walked in his boots.
Don’t look a gift horse in the mouth.
Don’t make a mountain out of a molehill.
Don’t put all your eggs in one basket.
american.description: Be careful! If you put all your goods in one bag or all your money in one stock, you are taking a big risk. It is smarter to spread your wealth around. That way if one basket should break, you’re not left with nothing.

american.text: Don’t put off for tomorrow what you can do today.
Don’t put the cart before the horse.
Don’t swing on my gate if you don’t like it.
Don’t throw caution to the wind.
Don’t throw dirt into the well that gives you water.
Don’t throw the baby out with the bathwater.
Don’t upset the apple cart.
Don’t use a lot where a little will do.
Don’t wish too hard: you might just get what you wished for.
Drive your business or it will drive you.
Dying is as natural as living soundly.
Dying men speak true.
Dynamite comes in small packages.
Eagles don’t catch flies.
Early childhood should be as happy and carefree as you can make it.
Easy come, easy go.
american.description: Money, fame, love or anything that happens easily can be lost just as quickly. If you get a lot of money or suddenly become famous, you could lose that money or fame very quickly—since you didn’t work hard to earn it.

american.text: Easy does it.
american.description: Be careful, don't go too fast.

american.text: Eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow we die.
Eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow your wife may come home.
Envy is left-handed praise.
Even an ass will not fall twice in the same quick sand.
Every doctor thinks his pills the best.
Every dog thinks her puppies are the cutest.
Every door may be shut but death’s door.
Every man has his hobby-horse.
